NAME: Geylang Serai
DESCRIPTIO: Geylang Serai is a social centre for the Malay community in Singapore. It was originally filled with lemongrass (â€œseraiâ€� in Malay) plantations between the 1890s to early 1900s.
ADDRESSBUI: Main entrance of Geylanf Serai Market and Food Centre

NAME: Tan Tock Seng Hospital
DESCRIPTIO: This hospital was founded in 1844 by Tan Tock Seng, a philanthropic Hokkien Chinese pioneer, for the poor and destitute. Here, several firsts in Singapore's medical history were achieved.
ADDRESSBUI: Sinaran Drive entrance of Tan Tock Seng Hospital

NAME: Batu Berlayar
DESCRIPTIO: Batu Berlayar (â€œSailing Rockâ€�), together with a rock on the opposite shore of Tanjong Rimau, formed a gateway to the west of Keppel Harbour. It was blown up in 1848 to widen the harbourâ€™s entrance.
ADDRESSBUI: Batu Berlayar Point, near Car Park B, Labrador Nature Reserve

NAME: Outram Road Prison
DESCRIPTIO: Outram Road Prison was the main jail in Singapore until Changi Prison opened in 1937. Thereafter, it became a remand prison, housing opium addicts, juvenile delinquents, and political detainees.
ADDRESSBUI: Outram Park MRT Station, Exit B

NAME: Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple
DESCRIPTIO: This temple was built in 1884, showcasing a fine example of Chinese temple architecture and traditional craftsmanship. The temple played an important role in providing refuge for the sick, the wounded and the homeless during the Japanese Occupation.

NAME: Pulau Sejahat
DESCRIPTIO: Pulau Sejahat was designated as a British defence outpost. The military encampment on the island included gun emplacements, water tanks and observation towers.
ADDRESSBUI: Changi Beach Park Lamp Post A2-13 (113), near Car Park 2

NAME: Sri Krishnan Temple
DESCRIPTIO: This temple was built in 1870 and is one of the oldest Hindu temples in Singapore.

NAME: Queenstown Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: Queenstown was built in 1960s to meet housing shortage in Singapore after the Second World War. It is Singaporeâ€™s first satellite town â€“ an estate with amenities to meet residentsâ€™ needs.

NAME: Sri Senpaga Vinayagar Temple
DESCRIPTIO: This temple was built by Ceylon Tamils. It began in an attap shed under a champak (â€œsenpagaâ€� in Tamil) tree in 1875, located near the discovery site of a statue of Vinayagar (the deity Ganesha).

NAME: United Overseas Bank
DESCRIPTIO: On 1 October 1935, UOB opened for business at the Bonham Building in Raffles Place. Over the years, it grew to become one of Singaporeâ€™s leading banks.
ADDRESSBUI: UOB Plaza One

NAME: MacRitchie Reservoir
DESCRIPTIO: Singaporeâ€™s first reservoir was officially opened in 1878 as the Impounding Reservoir, to supply freshwater for the growing population. It has also been a popular place for recreation over the years.
ADDRESSBUI: At the foot of Hilltop, Macritchie Reservoir Park

NAME: Lower Peirce Reservoir
DESCRIPTIO: This is Singaporeâ€™s second reservoir, constructed after water demand outgrew the capacity of MacRitchie Reservoir. It was known as Kalang River Reservoir when it opened in 1912.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Jetty, Lower Peirce Reservoir Park

NAME: Kempeitai East District Branch
DESCRIPTIO: The original building, the YMCA, was used by the East Branch of the Kempeitai (Japanese Military Police) during the Japanese Occupation. Local anti-Japanese suspects were imprisoned and tortured for information here. The building was pulled down in 1981.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Fort Canning Road and Orchard Road, beside YMCA

NAME: Kandang Kerbau Hospital
DESCRIPTIO: Kandang Kerbau Hospital, the birthplace of over 1.2 million Singaporeans, was the largest maternity hospital in the world from the early 1950s to the early 1970s. It was named after the district where it was located. The district around the crossroads fo
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Bukit Timah Road and Tekka Lane

NAME: Deng Xiaoping Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: Originally known as Deng Xiansheng and his school name Deng Xixian, Deng Xiaoping was born on 22 August 1904 in Guang'an County, Sichuan Province. In 1920, Deng left forÂ studies in France. His six-year stay in France proved to be a turning point in hi
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum

NAME: Central Sikh Temple
DESCRIPTIO: Also known as the Wadda Gurdwara, this Sikh temple was the first set up in a bungalow at Queen Street in 1912. The temple is now relocated at Towner Road.
ADDRESSBUI: In front of #01-234

NAME: Bukit Batok Memorials
DESCRIPTIO: Two memorials, one for the Japanese soldiers and the other for Allied Soldiers sat on top on this hill-top. The former was Syonan Chureito, built by 500 Allied Prisoners of War while the latter was a wooden cross that stood behind.
ADDRESSBUI: Bukit Batok Nature Park

NAME: Battle of Bukit Timah
DESCRIPTIO: One of the fiercest military encounters during WWII took place here as the Bukit Timah area held strategic and tactical importance to the Japanese and the British. This site marks Percival's final defence of southern Singapore against the Japanese invade
ADDRESSBUI: Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, near visitor centre, Bukit Timah Hill

NAME: Balestier Plain
DESCRIPTIO: Balestier Road, from which Balestier Plain takes its name, was named after Joseph Balestier, a keen botanist and agriculturist who arrived in Singapore in 1834. He was appointed as the first U.S Consul in Singapore in 1836 by then President of the United
ADDRESSSTR: Balestier Road, Beside Bus Stop No. 50239, Near Ceylon Sports Club

NAME: Anglo-Chinese School
DESCRIPTIO: The Anglo-Chinese School (ACS) was founded by Rev. William Fitzjames Oldham in 1886 at a shophouse in Amoy Street. Starting with 13 students, the school aimed to provide an education for the many boys Bishop Fitzjames saw wandering aimlessly in the stree

NAME: Alexandra Hospital
DESCRIPTIO: Opened in 1940, the Alexandra Hospital (former British Military Hospital) served as the principal hospital for Britainâ€™s Far East Command during World War II. The hospital was the most-advanced and best-equipped medical institution in Singapore an
ADDRESSBUI: Garden Valley at Alexandra Hospital

NAME: Adam Park
DESCRIPTIO: Adam park estate was the site of intense fighting between British forces and the invading Japanese army in February 1942, in the last days before the British surrendered Singapore.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Adam Road and Adam Park, near 7 Adam Park

NAME: Changi Beach Massacre
DESCRIPTIO: Changi Beach was a massacre site of Sook Ching. The Hojo Kempei (Japanese auxiliary military police) machine-gunned many male civilians on this shore on 20 February 1942.
ADDRESSBUI: Changi Beach Park Lamp Post A2-13 (113), Near Car Park 2

NAME: Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation
DESCRIPTIO: OCBC Bank was formed in 1932 through the merger of three Hokkien banks. It was originally located at China Building which featured a prominent Chinese-style roof and classical elements on its faÃ§ade.
ADDRESSBUI: North Tower OCBC Headquarters

NAME: Fuk Tak Chi
DESCRIPTIO: This building housed Fuk Tak Chi (â€œFu De Ciâ€� in Mandarin), one of the Singaporeâ€™s oldest Chinese temples, from the 1820s to 1994. It was later converted into a museum.
ADDRESSBUI: Far East Square

NAME: Sime Road Machine-Gun Pillbox
DESCRIPTIO: This pillbox was located inland to provide fire cover and defence for key installations in Bukit Timah during the Second World War.
ADDRESSBUI: Lamp Post 32, near Singapore Island Country Club (Island Location) Entrance

NAME: Peoplesâ€™ Defence Force Headquarters
DESCRIPTIO: In the early days of the SAF and Singaporeâ€™s independence, the Singapore Infantry Regiment and the PDF shouldered the duties of national defence. The Beach Road Army Camp played a significant role in the transformation.
ADDRESSBUI: Former Beach Road Camp, South Beach Development

NAME: Gan Eng Seng School
DESCRIPTIO: In 1885, Gan Eng Seng founded a free school for poor boys in Singapore. Initially named the Anglo-Chinese Free School, it was among the earliest schools to offer a bilingual education. The school moved to its first new building about 50 metres behind Tel
ADDRESSSTR: Junction of Telok Ayer Street and Cecil Street
ADDRESSBUI: Landscape Plaza

NAME: Sentosa Beach Massacre Site
DESCRIPTIO: Surrendered British Gunners awaiting Japanese internment buried some 300 bullet-ridden corpses washed ashore on Pulau Blakang Mati, now known as Sentosa.
ADDRESSBUI: Former Berhala Reping Artillery Post, Serapong Course Road, Course 4, Sentosa Golf Club

NAME: Chui Eng Free School
DESCRIPTIO: Chui Eng Free School was established here in 1854 by the Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan. It was the second-oldest private Chinese school and also one of the first free educational institutions in Singapore.
ADDRESSBUI: Far East Square

NAME: Omar Kampong Malacca Mosque
DESCRIPTIO: Established in 1820, Omar Kampong Malacca Mosque is Singaporeâ€™s oldest mosque. In the 1850s, the original timber structure made way for the current building to accommodate the mosqueâ€™s growing needs.

NAME: Upper Seletar Reservoir
DESCRIPTIO: Singaporeâ€™s third reservoir was constructed in 1920 to meet the increased demand for freshwater in Singapore. The iconic lookout tower was added to the reservoir in the 1960s.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Lookout Tower, Upper Seletar Reservoir Park, Mandai Road Track 7

NAME: Jalan Besar Stadium
DESCRIPTIO: Jalan Besar Stadium was Singaporeâ€™s main football arena until the National Stadium opened. It also hosted various national events, such as Singapore Youth Festival and National Day Parade.
ADDRESSBUI: North entrance of Jalan Besar Stadium

NAME: Beach Road Police Station
DESCRIPTIO: In the early 1900s, Singapore grew rapidly and the crime rate rose with the city's expansion. Harold Fariburn - the Inspector - General of Police from 1925 to 1935 - realised that the Police needed a programme of modernisation and expansion. As a result,

NAME: Pearl's Hill School
DESCRIPTIO: Pearlâ€™s Hill School began in 1876 at Cross Street as the Singapore Chinese Branch School. It was among the first English elementary schools established by the colonial government.

NAME: Katong Park
DESCRIPTIO: This is one of the oldest parks in Singapore. Built in the 1930s, it was a favourite place for families and couples, with facilities such as swimming bays which extended into the sea and food outlets.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Amphitheatre at Katong Park

NAME: Singapore Badminton Hall
DESCRIPTIO: Singapore Badminton Hall was built to host international badminton tournaments. In 1962, it was a vote-counting station for the Referendum on Singaporeâ€™s merger with Malaya, Sabah and Sarawak.

NAME: Clifford Pier
DESCRIPTIO: Clifford Pier was the landing point for sea passengers and immigrants who came to seek a new life in Singapore. It is also known as â€œRed Lantern Pierâ€� for the red lamps that hung here.
ADDRESSBUI: The Fullerton Bay Hotel

NAME: Havelock Road Camp / River Valley Road Camp
DESCRIPTIO: The area bounded by River Valley Road and Havelock Road was occupied by Prisoner-of-War (POW) camps during the Japanese Occupation. Five thousand POWs lived in dilapidated attap huts here.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside bus stop no. 13059, Valley Point Shopping Centre

NAME: Kallang Airport
DESCRIPTIO: This is Singaporeâ€™s first purpose-built civil airport. Completed in 1937, the modern-style terminal building symbolised the rapid civil aviation progress then. The airport ceased operations in 1955.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Kallang Airport Way and Stadium Link, beside gate to Former Kallang Airport

NAME: Sime Road Camp
DESCRIPTIO: Sime Road Camp was the Combined Headquarters of the British Army and Air Force during the Second World War, until the headquarters relocated to Fort Canning Command Centre.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction between Adam Road and Sime Road, near Bus Stop No. 41141

NAME: Kallang Gasworks
DESCRIPTIO: Built in 1862, Kallang Gasworks was Singaporeâ€™s first supplier of piped gas. It played an important role in ensuring efficient gas production for Singapore.
ADDRESSBUI: Kampong Bugis End, opposite Kallang Riverside Park

NAME: St. Margaret's School
DESCRIPTIO: St. Margaretâ€™s School began as a girlsâ€™ home at North Bridge Road in 1842, to rescue girls who were homeless or being sold to slavery.
ADDRESSBUI: St. Margaret's Primary School

NAME: Methodist Girls' School
DESCRIPTIO: Methodist Girlsâ€™ School began in 1887 as Tamil Girlsâ€™ School in a shophouse at Short Street with nine Indian girls.
ADDRESSSTR: Junction of Selegie Road and Short Stree, Beside 100 Selegie Road

NAME: Joseph Conrad Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: Joseph Conrad, the renowned English master writer, was of Polish origin and travelled to Singapore and south east asia during his seafaring days. He made Singapore and Southeast asia better known to the world through his writings.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Fullerton Hotel

NAME: Chen Wen Hsi Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: This was formerly the home of Chen Wen Hsi, one of Singaporeâ€™s pioneer artists. Chenâ€™s works mixed Western and Chinese traditions, and continued to influence local artists after his demise in 1991.

NAME: The First Public Dental School and Public Clinic
DESCRIPTIO: Dental Education and modern dentistry in Singapore began here in 1929. The original Clinic and Dental School of the King Edward VII college of Medicine had its beginnings on this site in the Norris Block of the General Hospital. In 1938, the clinic expan
ADDRESSBUI: Link Bridge between National Dental Centre Singapore and Health Promotion Board

NAME: Silat Road Sikh Temple
DESCRIPTIO: This temple was built in 1924 on Silat Road (today Jalan Bukit Merah). It was also known as the Police Gurdwara (a Sikh place of worship) as its congregation was mostly made up of Sikh policemen.

NAME: Merdeka Bridge
DESCRIPTIO: Merdeka Bridge, declared open on 17 August 1956, was constructed to ease traffic congestion. Its name reflects Singaporeâ€™s aspirations for independence (â€œmerdekaâ€� in Malay) then.
ADDRESSSTR: Merdeka Bridge, Nicoll Highway, beside lamp post 88F

NAME: Johore Battery
DESCRIPTIO: Completed in the late 1930s, Johore Battery was part of Singaporeâ€™s coastal defence system. It comprised three 15-inch guns known as â€œmonster gunsâ€�.
ADDRESSSTR: Cosford Road, Off Upper Changi Road

NAME: Singapore Armed Forces Warrant Officers' and Specialists' Club
DESCRIPTIO: The British Government built the clubhouse in 1951 for British non-commissioned officers. It was handed over to Singapore Government when the British pulled out in 1969.The SAF WOSE club was formed in 1974 and was formerly known as the SAF NCO Club until
ADDRESSBUI: Former NCO Buildings, South Beach Development

NAME: Punggol Beach Massacre
DESCRIPTIO: Punggol Beach was a massacre site of Sook Ching. Several men were killed by the Hojo Kempei (Japanese auxiliary military police) on this beach on 28 February 1942.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Jetty at Punggol Point Park

NAME: Jurong-Kranji Defence Line
DESCRIPTIO: This is an arbitrary defence line from Kranji River to Jurong River, placed to check Japanese advance towards the city from the west.
ADDRESSBUI: Jurong West Neighbourhood Park

NAME: United Chinese Library
DESCRIPTIO: United Chinese Library was founded by Dr Sun Yat Sen on 8 August 1910 at North Boat Quay, to spread revolutionary ideas and garner support for Dr Sunâ€™s revolution in China.

NAME: Singapore Polytechnic
DESCRIPTIO: Established in 1954, Singapore Polytechnic is the first technical institution in Singapore to train skilled labour. The Prince Edward Campus began operations on 3 November 1958 with 2,800 students.
ADDRESSBUI: Bestway Building

NAME: National Theatre
DESCRIPTIO: Officially opened on 8 August 1963, this theatre was built to commemorate the attainment of Singaporeâ€™s self-government in 1959. It was demolished in 1986 due to structural reasons.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of River Valley Road and Clemnceau Avenue, Beside Fort Canning Park

NAME: Pasir Panjang Machine-Gun Pillbox
DESCRIPTIO: This pillbox lay within the area guarded by the 1st Battalion of the Malay Regiment during the Second World War, to protect key installations in the Southern area, such as Alexandra Military Hospital.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Pasir Panjang Road and Science Park Road, Beside Shell Petrol Station

NAME: Seletar Airfield
DESCRIPTIO: Seletar Airfield was the British Royal Air Forceâ€™s main base in the Far East, equipped to protect the Sembawang naval base. Indian Prisoners-of-War were interned here during the Japanese Occupation.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside 1 Piccadilly Circus, near Former Seletar Camp Gate, Bus Stop No. 68111

NAME: Lower Barracks
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Pearl's Hill and Eu Tong Sen Street, opposite Pearl's Centre

NAME: Keppel Harbour
DESCRIPTIO: Keppel Harbour has been a thriving maritime gateway for trade since the late 19th century. During the Second World War, Operation Jaywick successfully destroyed seven Japanese ships here.
ADDRESSBUI: Harbourfront Walk End, Promenade between Harbourfront Centre and Vivocity

NAME: Jose Rizal Historic Marker
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum

NAME: Jawaharlal Nehru Historic Marker
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum

NAME: Ho Chi Minh Historic Marker
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Anderson Bridge, on the grounds of the Asian Civilisations Museum

NAME: Fort Canning Command Centre
DESCRIPTIO: Fort Canning Command Centre was the site where Lieutenant-General Arthur Percival and his commanders decided to surrender Singapore to the Japanese on 15 February 1942.
ADDRESSBUI: Battlebox Entrance, Fort Canning Park

NAME: Force 136 Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: Force 136 was a British secret service team that operated in Malaya during the Second World War. One of the agents was Lim Bo Seng, who led Gustavus V Operation in 1943. His grave is in the vicinity.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside zig-zag bridge to Pavailion, MacRitchie Reservoir Park

NAME: Execution of Captured Rimau Commandos Historic Marker
DESCRIPTIO: Operation Rimau (â€œtigerâ€� in Malay) was the second Allied commando attack on Japanese ships in Keppel Harbour. It failed, and ten commandos were beheaded by the Japanese near Dover and Clementi Roads.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Bus Stop No. 19059, Near NUS U-town Dover Road Entrance

NAME: Block A of Phoenix Park
ADDRESSBUI: Block A

NAME: United Engineers Limited
DESCRIPTIO: UEL was founded in 1912. It led major construction projects that contributed to Singaporeâ€™s urbanisation and economic growth, and built many iconic structures including the Former Supreme Court.
ADDRESSBUI: River Valley Road Entrance of UE Square

NAME: Gate of Hope
DESCRIPTIO: From a small gate here, the compassionate sisters of the Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus took in many abandoned infants and children. A replica, named â€œGate of Hopeâ€�, was installed here in 1996.

NAME: Institute of Mental Health
DESCRIPTIO: The Mental Hospital was completed in 1928 at Yio Chu Kang Road. It was renamed â€œWoodbridge Hospitalâ€� after a nearby wooden bridge, and then â€œThe Institute of Mental Healthâ€� after moving here in 1993.
ADDRESSBUI: Main entrance of Buangkok Green Medical Park

NAME: Raffles Place
DESCRIPTIO: Raffles Place was designated as Singaporeâ€™s business centre in the 1822 Town Plan. Singaporeâ€™s earliest banks, merchant houses and department stores were situated here.
ADDRESSBUI: Raffles Place MRT Station, Exit A

NAME: Custom House, Maxwell Road
DESCRIPTIO: This was the headquarters of Singapore Customs from 1932 to 1989. The building also housed the Film Censorâ€™s Office and the Maxwell Road Post Office.

NAME: Yeung Ching School
DESCRIPTIO: Yeung Ching School began in 1905 as a private school for Cantonese children. Apart from conducting classes in the day, it offered night classes to children who were poor or overaged.
ADDRESSBUI: Land Parcel Beside 65 Club Street

NAME: Withdrawal to Singapore
DESCRIPTIO: During the Second World War, the last Allied military troop in Malaya withdrew to Singapore through the Causeway on 31 January 1942, after losing Malaya to the Japanese.
ADDRESSBUI: WOODLANDS WATERFRONT PARK, NEAR LAMP POST 1R-32

NAME: Singapore Chin Kang Huay Kuan
DESCRIPTIO: Established in 1918 by Chinese Immigrants from the Jin Jiang County of southern Fujian Province, it was the headquarters of the Overseas Chinese Mobilisation Council, formed in 1941 to help Singaporeâ€™s defence against the Japanese.

NAME: Farrer Park
DESCRIPTIO: Farrer Park was the site of the first race course in Singapore, and continued to be a venue for numerous sporting events. It was a site for political gatherings and demonstrations in the 1940s and 1950s.
ADDRESSBUI: Walkway to Block 11, Gloucester Road, near Farrer Park MRT Station Exit D

NAME: Raffles Institution
DESCRIPTIO: The first school in Singapore, it was founded by Sir Stamford Raffles on 5 June 1823. It was originallly known as â€œThe Institutionâ€�.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of North Bridge Road and Stamford Road, beside Raffles City

NAME: Victoria Memorial Hall
DESCRIPTIO: Designed by colonial engineer, John Bennett, the theatre portion of the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall was built as a Town Hall in 1862 which housed the Municipal Offices.

NAME: Trinity Theological College
DESCRIPTIO: Trinity Theological College was born out of the camaraderie and spirit of Christianity experienced by the heads of the Anglican, Methodist and Presbyterian Churches when they were interned at Changi Prison during the Japanese Occupation. Founded on 4th O

NAME: Sook Ching Inspection Centre
DESCRIPTIO: This site marks one of many temporary registration centres set up by the Kempeitai(Japanese Military Police) to screen anti-Japanese Chinese.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Upper Cross Street and South Bridge Road

NAME: Labrador Battery
DESCRIPTIO: This is one of the surviving gun emplacements in Singapore today. The battery has two 6â€� 16-ton guns facing south, which aided the Malay Regiment in the Battle for Pasir Panjang by firing high explosive shells at the advancing Japanese troops alon
ADDRESSBUI: Near History Walk, Labrador Nature Reserve

NAME: Pasir Panjang Battle
DESCRIPTIO: The Battle for Pasir Panjang, where the harbour and British military depots were the coveted gains, marked one of the last battles for Singapore. It lasted from 12 to 14 February 1942.
ADDRESSBUI: Kent Ridge Park, beside Car Park B

NAME: Kranji Beach Battle
DESCRIPTIO: It was here on 9 February 1942 that the Japanese forces suffered a major loss, fighting against the valiant 27th Australian Brigade and the Dalforce.
ADDRESSBUI: Kranji Reservoir Park, Kranji Way, near Pavilion area

NAME: Sarimbun Beach Landing
DESCRIPTIO: On 8 February 1942, Japanese forces first landed in Singapore on this beach.
ADDRESSBUI: Beside Ministry of Education of Jalan Bahtera Adventure Centre

NAME: Japanese Propaganda Department
DESCRIPTIO: Formerly housing the British Malaya Broadcasting Corporations before WWII, it was turned into a Japanese propaganda office during the Japanese Occupation. It was later also used by Lord Louis Mountbatten as the headquarters for the Japanese Surrender in
ADDRESSBUI: Handy Road open space, beside The Cathay

NAME: Queen Elizabeth Walk
DESCRIPTIO: This was the site of sporting activities in the early days and became popular with families. In 1953, as part of the Coronation Celebrations, the seafront promenade was refurbished and renamed Queen Elizabeth Walk.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Promenade Linking Esplanade Theatres and Queen Elizabeth Walk, Esplanade Park

NAME: Indian National Army Memorial
DESCRIPTIO: The local INA, influenced by Subhas Chandra Bose, was formed in 1942 with Japanese support, with the aim of liberating India from British.
ADDRESSBUI: Queen Elizabeth Walk Esplanade Park, near Cenotaph

NAME: Sakya Muni Buddha Gaya Temple
DESCRIPTIO: Vutthisara, a monk from Thailand, founded the temple in 1927. This site is selected as both Indians and Chinese in an area predominantly settled it. It houses a Buddha statue of 15m talls and weighing 300 tonnes.

NAME: Singapore Chinese Girls' School
DESCRIPTIO: Singapore Chinese Girlsâ€™ School began in 1899 at Hill Street. It was founded by Straits Chinese pioneers to provide quality education for girls. The school was located here from 1925 to 1994.

NAME: Raffles Girls' School
DESCRIPTIO: Raffles Girlsâ€™ School began in 1844 as a girlsâ€™ department in Singapore Institution (today Raffles Institution), and became independent in 1879. It was located here from 1928 to 1979.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction of Stamdord Road and Armenian Street, beside Lee Kong Chian School of Business, Singapore Management University

NAME: Ee Hoe Hean Club
DESCRIPTIO: Founded in 1895, it is one of the oldest millionaires club in Singapore. The club was the centre of the Chinese Salvation Movement in Southeast Asia from 1937-1942. Originally located at Duxton Hill, it moved to Club Street before settling at this locati

NAME: Syonan Jinja
DESCRIPTIO: Syonan Jinja was built in 1942 in memory of the Japanese soldiers who died fighting in the invasion of Singapore. Ceremonies for significant events were held here until it was destroyed after the war.
ADDRESSBUI: Junction between Adam Road and Sime Road, near Bus Stop No. 41141

NAME: The Founding of Boys' Brigade in Singapore
DESCRIPTIO: Singaporeâ€™s first company of the Boysâ€™ Brigade was formed here on 12 January 1930. From a small company of 12, the Boysâ€™ Brigade in Singapore has since grown to a strength of more than 100 companies.
ADDRESSBUI: Prinsep Street Presbyterian Church

NAME: Middle Road Church
DESCRIPTIO: Built between 1870-75, the Middle Road Church was first known as the Christian Institute. When it was officially inaugurated as the Malay Church in 1894, it became the first Straits Chinese Methodist Church in Singapore.

NAME: Pondok Peranakan Gelam Club
DESCRIPTIO: Singaporeâ€™s last pondok (communal lodging house) was located here from 1932 to 2000. It served the welfare of Baweanese immigrants from the Gelam province of Indonesiaâ€™s Bawean Island.

NAME: Republic of Singapore Yacht Club
DESCRIPTIO: Founded in 1826, this club became the Royal Singapore Yacht Club in 1922 under the patronage of the Prince of Wales, and was renamed the Republic of Singapore Yacht Club in 1967 with the first president of Singapore, Yusof bin Ishak as it patrons.

NAME: Changi Murals
DESCRIPTIO: The Changi Murals was a symbol of hope and faith for prisoners during the Japanese Occupation. It depicted scenes from the Bible, and were painted by Stanley Warren, a Prisoner-of-War.
ADDRESSBUI: Side Entrance of Changi Museum
